Then Job answered and said,
I have heard many such things: miserable comforters <FI>are<Fi> ye all.<RF>miserable: or, troublesome<Rf>
Shall vain words have an end? or what emboldeneth thee that thou answerest?<RF>vain…: Heb. words of wind<Rf>
I also could speak as ye <FI>do<Fi>: if your soul were in my soul's stead, I could heap up words against you, and shake mine head at you.
<FI>But<Fi> I would strengthen you with my mouth, and the moving of my lips should asswage <FI>your grief<Fi>.<CM>
Though I speak, my grief is not asswaged: and <FI>though<Fi> I forbear, what am I eased?<RF>what…: Heb. what goeth from me?<Rf>
But now he hath made me weary: thou hast made desolate all my company.
And thou hast filled me with wrinkles, <FI>which<Fi> is a witness <FI>against me<Fi>: and my leanness rising up in me beareth witness to my face.
He teareth <FI>me<Fi> in his wrath, who hateth me: he gnasheth upon me with his teeth; mine enemy sharpeneth his eyes upon me.
They have gaped upon me with their mouth; they have smitten me upon the cheek reproachfully; they have gathered themselves together against me.
God hath delivered me to the ungodly, and turned me over into the hands of the wicked.<RF>hath…: Heb. hath shut me up<Rf>
I was at ease, but he hath broken me asunder: he hath also taken <FI>me<Fi> by my neck, and shaken me to pieces, and set me up for his mark.
His archers compass me round about, he cleaveth my reins asunder, and doth not spare; he poureth out my gall upon the ground.
He breaketh me with breach upon breach, he runneth upon me like a giant.
I have sewed sackcloth upon my skin, and defiled my horn in the dust.
My face is foul with weeping, and on my eyelids <FI>is<Fi> the shadow of death;<CM>
Not for <FI>any<Fi> injustice in mine hands: also my prayer <FI>is<Fi> pure.
O earth, cover not thou my blood, and let my cry have no place.
Also now, behold, my witness <FI>is<Fi> in heaven, and my record <FI>is<Fi> on high.<RF>on high: Heb. in the high places<Rf>
My friends scorn me: <FI>but<Fi> mine eye poureth out <FI>tears<Fi> unto God.<RF>scorn me: Heb. are my scorners<Rf>
O that one might plead for a man with God, as a man <FI>pleadeth<Fi> for his neighbour!<RF>neighbour: or, friend<Rf>
When a few years are come, then I shall go the way <FI>whence<Fi> I shall not return.<RF>a few…: Heb. years of number<Rf><CM>
